awd_titl_txt: Graduate Student Participation and CCD Procurement for the Original PolyOculus Array
awd_abstract_narration:
This project continues development of a new telescope configuration that is referred to as PolyOculus, which enables large telescope arrays at significantly lower cost. This allows smaller universities and colleges with limited budgets to engage in forefront research.  The system uses small amateur telescopes to create robotic light collectors. These units are pointed at the same target and the light is fed into custom fiber optic cables. A photonic lantern is used to combine the light from the parallel fibers.  Light can be further combined again with other similar units to make even bigger telescopes. The PolyOculus system would serve as a pathfinder for studies of targets identified by the Vera Rubin Observatory, to study the nature of Dark Energy and search for Earth-like planets. 
 
Follow-up spectroscopy is scientifically important for identifying the basic nature of new sources that are being discovered by time series observation of the night sky (e.g. supernovae, flare stars, tidal disruption events, or new classes of objects), for determining the key physical properties of these events(temperature, composition, radial velocity, outflows, etc.) and to follow the evolution of those properties with time.  Traditional large spectroscopic facilities are expensive to construct. This project will develop a method for producing large-area-equivalent telescopes by using photonic technology to link multiple semi-autonomous, small, inexpensive, commercial-off-the-shelf telescopes. Crucially, this scalable design has construction costs which are substantially lower than equivalent traditional large-area telescopes. This project’s innovative array approach represents a new approach to obtaining spectroscopic follow-up for time-domain astronomy. Two graduate students will be engaged in the deployment and commissioning of the instrument at the Mount Laguna Observatory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funded effort has significantly advanced the Original PolyOculus Array (OPA) project, and its continued deployment with non-Federal funds will demonstrate the PolyOculus technology for the first time in the field. Crucially, this scalable approach has construction costs which are 10 times lower than equivalent traditional large-area telescopes. This innovative PolyOculus array approach represents a transformational technology for spectroscopic followup in time-domain astronomy. 

The PolyOculus approach relies primarily on recent advances in low-cost, high-performance Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment - telescopes, CCD cameras, and control computers - combined with a novel photonic-link architecture and a few key technological innovations to produce telescope collecting areas equivalent to standard telescopes with mirror diameters ranging from 0.9-m to 40-m and beyond for certain applications. The basic module in this scalable design consists of a 7-pack of small COTS telescopes which are semi-autonomous in their pointing, tracking, and focus control, equipped with an autonomous novel acquisition/guiding system and a photonic fiber optic feed. The fiber optic outputs are linked together via a photonic lantern and switching system which also provides intensity metering for the automated acquisition system. The linked 7-pack output can then be further linked to other 7-packs in a hierarchical, scalable architecture, or it can be fed directly into a common, shared detection system. The switching approach allows the dynamic reconfiguration of this system from a single large aperture to multiple, independently-pointable/operable smaller apertures on timescales of ~60 seconds for rapid response spectroscopic followup.

To enable spectroscopic follow-up for Evryscope and other current surveys, and also to serve as a pathfinder for low-cost spectroscopic facilities in the LSST era, we are currently developing the Original PolyOculus Array (OPA) with University of Central Florida (UCF)  internal funds. OPA will be co-sited with Evryscope-North at the Mount Laguna Observatory in southern California, with a small, low-cost double spectrograph as its scientific detector unit. With the equivalent collecting area of a 0.9-meter traditional telescope and spectral resolution R~2000, OPA will search at low-latency for Coronal Mass Ejection spectroscopic signatures in M-dwarf superflares — critical for our understanding of exoplanet habilitabilit

PolyOculus provides a potentially transformational shift in community access to spectroscopic facilities. With OPA we will demonstrate the ability to construct such a facility for a fraction of the cost of a traditional observatory. This approach both paves the way for larger, nationally funded facilities in the Vera Rubin Observatory era, and opens the door for smaller universities and colleges with limited budgets, including primarily undergraduate institutions, to engage in forefront research with privately funded, dedicated arrays. PolyOculus technology also has strong potential for application in spece-to-ground optical satellite communications and in atmospheric LIDAR sensing for atmospheric science. In both cases, PolyOculus can enable lower-cost receiver stations, allowing larger and/or multiplexed deployments at low cost. This project has already led to plans to deploy a related system at Cerro Pachon in Chile for Atmospheric LIDAR.
